title: Bionic Human and the Future of Being Human
description: (UGEB1217 is double-coded with BMEG1217.) This course exposes students to a range of state-of-the-arts developments in biomedical engineering. It invites students from various disciplines to discuss the long-term societal impacts and ethical implications of these technological advances, particularly in human enhancements beyond therapy. The course starts by illustrating the many amazing designs in our human body and yet how vulnerable we are in terms of injuries, diseases and ageing. Examples on how modern biomedical engineering helps us face our human conditions are given, such as musculoskeletal prosthetics and orthotics, cardiovascular implants, neuroengineering, stem cells and regenerative medicine, gene editing, bionanotechnology, intelligence and artificial intelligence and senses and artificial senses, etc. A historical account of human quest for “living” machine, including a brief coverage of modern movies on bionic human then follows. The course wraps up with some social, ethical and philosophical reflections on the above issues and on the meaning of being human, opening up questions concerning the perennial human quest of becoming super human.

title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG1130 or BMEG2001 or BMEG2130 or ESTR2200 or ESTR2201.
description: This course covers the definition, scope, basic principles and problems in biomedical engineering, introduction to the enabling technologies for biomedical engineering. It provides the overview of various topics in biomedical engineering, e.g., biomedical sensors, bioinstrumentation, bio-signal processing, biomechanics, biomaterials, molecular engineering, tissue engineering, bio-nanotechnology, medical imaging and rehabilitation engineering, etc. It covers the applications of engineering principles to selected medical and biological problems and contemporary roles and challenges of biomedical engineering.

title: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG1130 or BMEG2011 or BMEG2130 or ESTR2202 or ESTR2203.;Co-requisite: ELEG2202 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course provides a hands-on experience in various aspects of biomedical engineering. It covers the introduction to basic electronics, chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, and electrophysiology laboratory techniques, laboratory skills, experimental design, interpretation of data, technical writing and ethical issues relevant to laboratory work. It concludes with a student-driven design project.

title: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory and Hospital Experience
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG1130 or BMEG2010 or BMEG2130 or ESTR2202 or ESTR2203.;Co-requisite: ELEG2202 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course provides hands-on experience in various aspects of biomedical engineering, introduction to basic electronics, chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, electrophysiology laboratory techniques and hospital visits. Laboratory skills, experimental design, interpretation of data, technical writing and safety and ethical issues relevant to laboratory work. It concludes with a student-driven design project.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to   - Undertake laboratory experiments using basic techniques in electronics, chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology and electrophysiology to support the study and solution of biomedical engineering problems; and   - Apply engineering design process to the conceptual design of a biomedical engineering device; and   - Document through a written report and an oral presentation the results of an engineering design project performed as part of a team of student engineers; and   - Exhibit good safety and teamwork skills and serve as effective members of multidisciplinary project teams; and  - Understand the fundamentals and daily operation of various medical instruments from the perspectives of end-users, (doctors, technicians, nurses) and recipients (patients) through observation and work shadowing; and  - Appreciate the role of biomedical engineers in hospitals, the importance of disinfection and aseptic techniques, experience the daily operation, information flow and logistics in the running of a hospital; and  - Relate theory and engineering knowledge to practicing in a real-world setting  This course meets the Course Learning Outcomes to the BEng (BME) Programme Outcomes 1 – 8.

title: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG1130 or BMEG2010 or BMEG2011 or BMEG2130 or ESTR2202 or ESTR2203 or ESTR2602.
description: This course provides hands-on experience in various aspects of biomedical engineering, including introduction to basic electronics, chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, electrophysiology laboratory techniques. Students will gain exposure to biological and chemical safety and other general safety issues. Students will also receive training on laboratory skills, design of experiments, interpretation of data and technical writing. This course concludes with a student-driven design project.

title: Orthopaedic Biomechanics and Musculoskeletal Injury
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR2204 or MAEG2020.
description: This course covers biostatics, biodynamics, and biosolid mechanics and their applications to the human musculoskeletal systems and the clinical practice of orthopaedics. Topics include: force and moment vectors, equations of equilibrium, moments of inertia, kinematics of particles, Newton’s second law, kinematics of rigid bodies, dynamics of rigid bodies, stress-strain relations, linear elasticity, loading and deformation, shear forces and bending moments, multi-body kinematics and application to skeletal system, musculoskeletal injury mechanisms associated with musculoskeletal biology (aging, gender, diseases, adverse effects of treatments) and external forces (sports and traffic accidences), basic principles for designing medical devices and implants for prevention and treatment of musculoskeletal injuries.Clinical scenarios will be presented with open-ended questions. Relevant laboratory sessions on musculoskeletal force analysis, human movement studies, animal tissue testing will be synergized with the corresponding lectures to enhance learning. Students are expected to have prior knowledge on the basic principles of Newtonian mechanics at secondary school level.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: - Explain the basic principles of biomechanics; - Apply the above principles to facilitate quantitative understanding of the normal functions of the musculoskeletal system for locomotion, postural control, and other daily activities; - Apply the above principles to analyze the biomechanical consequences of the pathological conditions of the musculoskeletal system, its injury mechanisms, how the system can adapt itself to meet its functional demands, and how clinical orthopaedic interventions may facilitate the healing of its derangements.
syllabus: This course covers biostatics, biodynamics, and biosolid mechanics and their applications to the human musculoskeletal systems and the clinical practice of orthopaedics. Topics include: force and moment vectors, equations of equilibrium, moments of inertia, kinematics of particles, Newton’s second law, kinematics of rigid bodies, dynamics of rigid bodies, stress-strain relations, linear elasticity, loading and deformation, shear forces and bending moments, multi-body kinematics and application to skeletal system, musculoskeletal injury mechanisms associated with musculoskeletal biology (aging, gender, diseases, adverse effects of treatments) and external forces (sports and traffic accidences), basic principles for designing medical devices and implants for prevention and treatment of musculoskeletal injuries. Clinical scenarios will be presented with open-ended questions. Relevant laboratory sessions on musculoskeletal force analysis, human movement studies, animal tissue testing will be synergized with the corresponding lectures to enhance learning. Students are expected to have prior knowledge on the basic principles of Newtonian mechanics at secondary school level.   More details will be provided when available.

title: Circuits and Signals for Biomedical Engineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG2202 or ENGG2030 or ESTR2206 or ESTR2601.
description: This required course covers basic circuit theory that are needed for understanding the operation, as well as design, of many biomedical devices. It also provides a theoretical and mathematical foundation for analyzing and processing of electrical signals. Students will learn the parametric concepts commonly used for the representation, analysis and transformation of continuous-time and discrete-time signals, and the principles of processing time-varying signals in linear systems. This course emphasizes on using mathematical methods to analyze and to solve engineering problems.Specific topics of this course are: basic circuit laws and theorems, mesh and nodal analysis, superposition and source transformation; analysis of operational amplifier circuits and their biomedical applications; concept of phasor and impedance; AC analysis, introduction to transient analysis; inductors and transformers for biomedical devices; Basics of biomedical signals; continuous-time and discrete-time signals and systems; Fourier series and Fourier transform for analysis of signals and systems; convolutions/filters; sampling.
outcome: Upon completing this course students will have the ability to: - State terminologies and concepts which are important in the field of circuit analysis and design. - Apply circuit laws to analyze a linear circuit that contains resistors, capacitors, inductors, dependent and independent sources. - Apply calculus and linear algebra in circuit analysis- Be able to simplify circuits for analysis using circuit theorems and transforms. - Apply complex numbers and Laplace transform in AC circuit analysis - Carry out circuit experiments independently and appreciate the importance of connecting theories to the real world through experiments - Analyze experimental results critically - understand the physical meanings of signals, and how they are mathematically represented and processed. - understand the concept of frequency, and the frequency domain analysis of signals. - understand the sampling theorem and its physical implications. - understand how to use the Fourier transform, filtering and convolution processes.
syllabus: This course covers basic circuit laws and theorems, mesh and nodal analysis, superposition and source transformation; analysis of operational amplifier circuits and their biomedical applications; concept of phasor and impedance; AC analysis; introduction to transient analysis; inductors and transformers for biomedical devices; basics of biomedical signals; continuous-time and discrete-time signals and systems; Fourier series and Fourier transform for analysis of signals and systems; convolutions/filters; biosignal sampling.
required_readings: Discrete-Time Signal Processing, 3rd Edition, Alan V. Oppenheim, Ronald W. Schafer, 2009  Fundamentals of Electric Circuits, 6e, Alexander & Sadiku, McGraw Hill, Fitzgerald & Kingsley, Electric Machinery, 7e, McGraw-Hill.

title: Complex Analysis and Differential Equations
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2420 or 2460 or ESTR2000 or 2010
description: This course covers complex analysis and differential equations. Topics of complex analysis include analytic functions, Cauchy Riemann, complex integration, Cauchy principal value, elementary complex valued functions, exponential functions, Euler's formula, trigonometric and hyperbolic functions, logarithm and general powers, power series, Taylor series and convergence tests. Topics of differential equations include classification of differential equations, 1st order ordinary differential equations, 2nd order ordinary differential equations, and partial differential equations.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to: 1.demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the basic elements of complex analysis  2.obtain competence to solve mathematical problems relevant to engineering with the 1st and 2nd order ordinary differential equations and partial differential equations  3.model engineering problems
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. M. D. Greenberg, Advanced Engineering Mathematics, 2nd edition, Prentice Hall, 1998. 2. E. Kreyszig, Advanced Engineering Mathematics, 9th edition, John Wiley, 2006.

title: Hospital Experience and Engineering Practicum
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2602.
description: This course aims to enrich student experience in hospital environment and appreciation of laboratory skills, engineering and electrical safety and ethical issues. Students will have the opportunity to visit various hospital facilities and laboratories. This course includes professional workshops on laboratory skills and appreciation of ethical issues relevant to the biomedical engineering discipline.

title: Medical Instrumentation and Design
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3101 or ESTR3210 or ESTR3601.
description: In view of the prevalence of the aging population and accompanying chronic illnesses, demands for medical instrumentation and design have been escalating worldwide. This course aims at enabling students to master design-thinking skills and by applying it to the broad medical fields. Laboratory sessions will be arranged to train students in developing prototypes and enrich their understanding of the fundamental design concepts covered in lectures.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students should be able to: 1. Give an overview of the origins of certain selected biological and physiological signals; 2. Understand the design process of various medical devices; 3. Evaluate the different classes of medical instruments and measurement principles; 4. Master some common medical instruments;  5. Foresee the future trend in related topics; 6. Design at least one new medical device that meets health demand;  7. Demonstrate ability to design new medical devices in a dynamic group setting; and  8. Have acquired design-thinking skills in producing prototypes that meet specific design goals.
syllabus: This course covers the fundamental concepts of design of medical instrumentation and sensors; origins and measurements of bioelectric and ultrasonic signals; electrical safety and hazard; and application examples including electrocardiography (ECG) measurements, pulse oximetry, biosensors cochlear implant devices, functional electric stimulators and drug delivery systems, etc. Students have to form groups to produce a medical device prototype that fulfills a list of design goals. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired basic engineering design skills and practical problem-solving skills that are directly transferable to further design work in their future careers.
recommended_readings: 1. Medical Instrumentation, 4th Edition, Ed. by John Webster. 2. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating Medical Technologies by Zenios, Makower and Yock. 3. Biomedical Transducers and Instruments by Togawa, Tamura, and Oberg. 4. Introduction to Biomedical Equipment Technology, 3rd Edition, by Carr and Brown.

title: Bioinformatics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4120.
description: This course introduces the basic concepts in bioinformatics. On the theoretical side, students are expected to learn the relevant knowledge in computer science, biology and mathematics from lectures and tutorials. On the practical side, they are given assignments and tutorials to get hands-on experience in locating, studying and using developed tools to apply the learned concepts in performing standard analytical tasks on biomedical data. Topics to be covered include: introduction to bioinformatics, reviews of molecular biology and genetics, biomedical data types and databases, sequence alignment and searching methods, mutation models and molecular phylogenetics, molecular structures, basics of human genetics and genetic diseases, clinical bioinformatics for genetic diseases diagnosis.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to - Tell the main ideas in bioinformatics, and its roles in biomedical engineering; and - Apply learned algorithms and skills to carry out standard analytical tasks, such as sequence alignment and phylogenetic tree reconstruction; and - Develop innovative engineering tools and software modules for bioinformatics analysis
syllabus: This course introduces the basic concepts in bioinformatics. On the theoretical side, students are expected to learn the relevant knowledge in computer science, biology and mathematics from lectures and tutorials. On the practical side, they are given assignments and tutorials to get hands-on experience in locating, studying and using developed tools to apply the learned concepts in performing standard analytical tasks on biomedical data. Topics to be covered include: introduction to bioinformatics, reviews of molecular biology and genetics, biomedical data types and databases, sequence alignment and searching methods, mutation models and molecular phylogenetics, molecular structures, basics of human genetics and genetic diseases, clinical bioinformatics for genetic diseases diagnosis. More details will be provided when available.

title: Big Data in HealthCare
description: This course will cover clinical ontologies and standards, clinical databases, electronic health record systems, event reporting systems, real-time monitoring systems, acquisition and mining of data from portable medical devices, heterogeneous data integration, topic models for free-text medical records, trend analysis and medical recommendation systems. Students form teams from different disciplines and each team would tackle a particular healthcare big data repository to go through the process of data analytics.

title: Data Analytics for Personalized Genomics and Precision Medicine
description: This course will cover high-throughput experimental methods, standard data processing pipelines, distributed and hardware-accelerated sequence alignment and assembly, pseudo-alignment, integration of heterogeneous sequencing and non-sequencing data, multi-omic analysis methods, genomic sequence compression, identification, annotation and prioritization of genetic variants, and privacy-aware data sharing.

title: Medical Instrumentation and Design
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG3101 or ELEG3101 or ESTR3210 or ESTR3601 or ESTR3603
description: In view of the prevalence of the aging population and accompanying chronic illnesses, demands for medical instrumentation and design have been escalating worldwide. This course aims at enabling students to master design-thinking skills and by applying them to the broad medical fields. Laboratory sessions and design project modules are arranged to train students in developing prototypes, enrich their understanding of the fundamental design concepts and microcontroller programme coding skills.

title: Database and Security for Biomedical Engineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken CSCI3170 or CSCI5470;Prerequisite: CSCI1120 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course introduces the fundamental applications of information technology for healthcare, with a focus on medical informatics, basic concepts of database management systems, security protocol, firewalls and computer viruses, system security threats and etc.

title: Tele-medicine and Mobile Healthcare
description: This course introduces remote and smartphone-based healthcare management. This course covers the basic technology of tele-medicine and m-health systems, including information types and transmission, communication systems and networks, picture archiving and communication system, hospital information system, medical data coding and compression, information privacy, confidentiality and data integrity, mobile biosensors and smartphones. It also covers public health informatics, risk prediction models and selected applications on ambulatory monitoring, tele-surgery, smart homes, and internet healthcare.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able: - To acquire basic knowledge of communication networks - To understand medical data coding and compression methods - To know basic of cryptography and security issues in mobile health - To have hands-on experience on developing a mini-project on smartphone-healthcare applications
syllabus: This course introduces remote and smartphone-based healthcare management. This course covers the basic technology of tele-medicine and m-health systems, including information types and transmission, communication systems and networks, picture archiving and communication system, hospital information system, medical data coding and compression, information privacy, confidentiality and data integrity, mobile biosensors and smartphones. It also covers public health informatics, risk prediction models and selected applications on ambulatory monitoring, tele-surgery, smart homes, and internet healthcare.

title: Molecular and Cellular Engineering Laboratory
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3604.
description: The course topics include biological and cellular laboratory safety and bioethics, basic molecular cloning skills (restriction enzyme cutting, ligation, and E Coli transformation) and mammalian cell culture techniques (cell culture maintenance, observation of cell growth and proliferation, analysis of cell death, genetic modification, cell staining)
outcome: By the end of this course, students are expected to: 1. Obtain knowledge of basic cell biology, molecular biology and biomedical engineering. 2. Demonstrate an ability to design and conduct molecular and cellular engineering experiments, as well as to analyze and interpret the data. 3. Demonstrate an ability to identify, formulate, and solve problems in molecular and cellular engineering experiments. 4. Demonstrate an ability to critically evaluate research and professional literature, and understand the principles and practice of conducting research in clinical and industrial environments related to molecular and cellular engineering.
syllabus: The course topics include biological and cellular laboratory safety and bioethics, basic molecular cloning skills (restriction enzyme cutting, ligation, and E Coli transformation) and mammalian cell culture techniques (cell culture maintenance, observation of cell growth and proliferation, analysis of cell death, genetic modification, cell staining)

title: Biofluids
requirements: Not for students who have taken MAEG3030 or ESTR3212.
description: This course introduces the fundamental knowledge in fluid mechanics, including nature of fluids, integral and differential equations of fluid flows, conservation of mass, momentum and energy, basic mass transfer, inviscid flow, viscous-dominated flows, navier-stokes equation, dimensional analysis, internal and external flows and reynolds number. It covers micro-fluidic devices and biological applications. It also describes fluids in human body and blood flow, including blood velocity, blood vessel geometry and respiratory mechanics.

title: Biomedical Imaging
requirements: Prerequisite: BMEG2300 or ENGG2030 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course covers the fundamentals of biomedical imaging: the physiology and physics that are involved in the imaging process (waves, spins, resonance, radioactive decay), the mathematics that are needed to modelize the image formation (linear algebra, multidimensional calculus, 2D Fourier transform, Radon transform, probabilities), the signal and image processing techniques that help analyse digital images (2D filtering, discrete 2D Fourier transform, interpolation, contrast, quality), and the hardware used for acquiring these images (X-ray tubes, detectors, magnets, coils, gamma cameras, transductors). A particular emphasis will be laid on four imaging modalities: X-ray radiography, Computed Tomography (CT), Emission Computed Tomography (scintigraphy, SPECT and PET), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Ultrasound Imaging.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired the ability to  1. Understand common techniques for generating and processing biomedical images.  2. Understand the physical principles, usages and limitations of each imaging modality.  3. Enumerate which physical or physiological properties can be measured with each modality.  4. Recognize the different imaging systems and their basic parts.  5. Understand the importance of using imaging as a tool for the study in biomedical engineering.  6. Obtain useful biomedical and health information from various types of biomedical images.
syllabus: This course teaches the fundamentals of biomedical imaging: the physiology and physics that are involved in the imaging process (waves, spins, resonance, radioactive decay), the mathematics that are needed to modelize the image formation (linear algebra, multidimensional calculus, 2D Fourier transform, Radon transform, probabilities), the signal and image processing techniques that help analyse digital images (2D filtering, discrete 2D Fourier transform, interpolation, contrast, quality), and the hardware used for acquiring these images (X-ray tubes, detectors, magnets, coils, gamma cameras, transductors). A particular emphasis will be laid on four imaging modalities: X-ray radiography, Computed Tomography (CT), Emission Computed Tomography (scintigraphy, SPECT and PET), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Ultrasound Imaging.  More information will be provided when available.
recommended_readings: Textbook: Medical Imaging Signals and Systems, by J     Textbook: Medical Imaging Signals and Systems, by J.L. Prince and J.M. Links (Pearson-Prentice Hall 2006).   Others: 1.          Fundamentals of Medical Imaging, by Paul Suetens (Cambridge University Press 2002). 2.          Gonzalez and Woods: Digital Image Processing, Addison Wesley, 3rd Edition, 2008.

title: Neuroengineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3602.
description: This course discusses the introduction of neuroengineering: the past, the current status and the future. The topics cover Neural system and neuron activity; Neural modeling and computation; Neural information processing, Neuromuscular systems and Electromyography (EMG); Brain-computer interface (BCI) and neuroprosthesis: functional electrical stimulation, retina and cochlea; Electric and magnetic field of human brain (EEG and MEG), transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS); Transcranial direct-current stimulation (tDCS); biopotential electrode and amplifier; Mechanisms underlying neurological disorders (stroke, Parkinson's disease or epilepsy); optogenetic technology, principles and applications of neuroimaging such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Selected state-of-the-art topics in a highly interdisciplinary field that combines neuroscience, electrophysiology, neural activity imaging, optics and engineering technologies. Other selected topics of recent research interests.
outcome: • Able to describe how to meet standards and regulatory requirements of medical devices in US, Europe and Asia. • Able to handle regulatory tasks included classification, risk management and product registration. • Design at least one new project that meets medical device regulatory requirements;  • Demonstrate ability to design new project in a dynamic group setting; and  • Have acquired design-thinking skills in producing the project that meet specific regulatory goals.
syllabus: This course discusses the introduction of neuroengineering: the past, the current status and the future. The topics cover Neural system and neuron activity; Neural modeling and computation; Neural information processing, Neuromuscular systems and Electromyography (EMG); Brain-computer interface (BCI) and neuroprosthesis: functional electrical stimulation, retina and cochlea; Electric and magnetic field of human brain (EEG and MEG), transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS); Transcranial direct-current stimulation (tDCS); biopotential electrode and amplifier; Mechanisms underlying neurological disorders (stroke, Parkinson's disease or epilepsy); optogenetic technology, principles and applications of neuroimaging such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Selected state-of-the-art topics in a highly interdisciplinary field that combines neuroscience, electrophysiology, neural activity imaging, optics and engineering technologies. Other selected topics of recent research interests.  A design project of an EEG device to enhance students engineering design skills and problem solving skills. A design project of an EEG device aims at enabling students to master design-thinking and, by following a problem-based group approach. Students have to form groups to produce a medical device prototype that fulfills a list of design goals. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired basic engineering design skills and practical problem-solving skills that are directly transferable to further design work in their future careers.
required_readings: 1. Medical devices - Quality management systems - Requirements for regulatory purposes ISO13485:2003, 2003 2. Medical devices - Application of risk management to medical devices ISO14971:2007, 2007 3. Council directive 93/42/EEC concerning medical devices, 2007  4. Handbook of medical device regulatory affairs in Asia, Jack Wong and Raymond Tong, Pan Stanford Publishing, 2013 5. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating New Medical Technologies, Stefanos A Zenios; Josh Makower; Paul G Yock , Cambridge University Press, 2010
recommended_readings: N/A

title: Medical Robotics
description: This course introduces medical robotics, mechanical structures and dynamics, robotic sensing and control, human-robot interface, surgical robotic systems, rehabilitation robotic systems, micro-scale robotic medical devices and state-of-the-art technologies in medical robotics.

title: Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3208.
description: This course introduces the fundamentals in design, fabrication and selection of biomaterials for medical applications. Topics include physical, chemical and mechanical properties and bio-compatibility of different types of biomaterials (e.g. natural, synthetic, inorganic and composite, etc), introduction to tissue engineering, principles of tissue engineering for medical application and physical and biological considerations of biomaterials applications in clinical indications.
outcome: Students are expected to: 1. Understand fundamentals of materials as applied to bioengineering 2. Apply natural and man-made materials to biological systems 3. Acquire basic knowledge on tissue engineering on the context of biomedical applications
syllabus: This course introduces the fundamentals in design, fabrication and selection of biomaterials for medical applications. Topics include physical, chemical and mechanical properties and bio-compatibility of different types of biomaterials (e.g. natural, synthetic, inorganic and composite, etc), introduction to tissue engineering, principles of tissue engineering for medical application and physical and biological considerations of biomaterials applications in clinical indications.  More details will be provided when available.
recommended_readings: 1         1.      Biomaterials: An Introduction, JB Park & RS Lakes, 3rd ed., 2007, Springer 2.    Biomechanics: Mechanical Properties of Living Tissues, YC Fung, 2nd ed., 1993, Springer

title: Global Engineering Medical Innovation
description: Many successful designs and startups begin in university years. This course involves projects that are led by students and aims at accelerating them to prepare for engineering medical innovation in which teams of students design and develop clinically-driven and client-centered engineering innovations for the future of medicine & healthcare. This course aims at enabling students to master design-thinking and, by following a problem-based group approach, apply it to the broad medical fields. Students have to form groups of size 2 to 4 to develop from an idea to become viable medical device in the market. In the process, students work on ideas, market research, prototyping, developing operation strategies, conducting pilot tests, designing market survey and preparing business proposal to sell their product or ideas. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired engineering design skills and entrepreneurship skills that are directly transferable to further innovation work.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students should be able to: 1. Write a business proposal and operation plan; 2. Prepare presentations to market their product or idea; 3. Understand the design process of various medical devices; 4. Design at least one new medical device that meets health demand;  5. Demonstrate ability to design new medical devices in a dynamic group setting; and  6. Have acquired design-thinking skills in producing prototypes that meet specific design goals.
syllabus: This course covers the fundamental concepts of design process of medical device and preparation of business proposal. Students have to form groups to produce a medical device and prepare a business proposal. Written reports, presentations, and/or business/operation plan are required. Students should have acquired basic engineering design skills and practical skills that are directly transferable to further innovation work in their future careers. To exemplify students’learnt abilities in problem-solving and in designing new medical devices, based on project-based learning practices, students are required to form groups to complete the following tasks as a group project:  - Define a problem/goal (in relation to medical or healthcare devices) provided or approved by course instructor;  - Understand the problem/goal, including the related complexities, uncertain parameters, and practical constraints, etc.;  - Conduct market search;  - Discuss and analyze findings;  - Develop and implement a detailed plan;  - Present the prototype in class;  - Receive and evaluate feedbacks provided by instructors and clinical professionals; and  - Write up a business proposal.
recommended_readings: 1. Medical Device Design: Innovation from Concept to Market, 2nd Edition, by Peter J. Ogrodnik 2. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating Medical Technologies, 2nd Edition by Paul G. Yock, Stefanos Zenios, et al. 3. Medical Instrumentation, 4th Edition, Ed. by John Webster. 4. Introduction to Biomedical Equipment Technology, 3rd Edition, by Carr and Brown.

title: Undergraduate Research in Biomedical Engineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG3920
description: Students will conduct research study of a topic in Biomedical Engineering under the supervision of a teaching staff.
outcome: By the end of the course, the student should have 1. Developed the capability for creative thinking in research 2. Acquired a basket of skills for performing research 3. Learnt how to prepare technical presentations and writings
syllabus: Students will conduct research study of a topic in Biomedical Engineering under the supervision of a teaching staff.
recommended_readings: Recommended readings will be provided by the supervisor of the undergraduate research project     Recommended readings will be provided by the supervisor of the undergraduate research project.

title: Global Medical Device Regulatory Affairs
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG5850 or ESTR4601.
description: This course provides an overview on global medical device regulation. Regulatory affairs refer to how to get a medical product registered in different countries’ health authorities. A registered product would demand a lot of technical documentation to prove its efficacy, safety, and quality. To successfully and smoothly register a product, knowledge and skills are required to deal with various key stakeholders in governments, testing centers, hospitals, and medical doctors. The course is characterized by its unique international focus. In addition to learning Hong Kong, Chinese Mainland and Asia regulatory affairs, students would learn European and US medical device regulatory system to facilitate the medical device to be marketed around the world.
outcome: • Able to describe how to meet standards and regulatory requirements of medical devices in US, Europe and Asia. • Able to handle regulatory tasks included classification, risk management and product registration.
syllabus: This course provides an overview on global medical device regulation. Regulatory affairs refer to how to get a medical product registered in different countries’ health authorities. A registered product would demand a lot of technical documentation to prove its efficacy, safety, and quality. To successfully and smoothly register a product, knowledge and skills are required to deal with various key stakeholders in governments, testing centers, hospitals, and medical doctors. The course is characterized by its unique international focus. In addition to learning Hong Kong, Chinese Mainland and Asia regulatory affairs, students would learn European and US medical device regulatory system to facilitate the medical device to be marketed around the world.  This course aims to give both factual and practical experiences on what is regulatory requirement and how to handle future regulatory tasks, included classification, risk management, product registration and commercial materials review.  Students would form teams from different disciplines and each team would tackle a particular medical device of their choices to go through the processes of the regulatory requirements. The project ideas will be put into the reality and through public channels.
required_readings: 1. Medical devices - Quality management systems - Requirements for regulatory purposes ISO13485:2003, 2003 2. Medical devices - Application of risk management to medical devices ISO14971:2007, 2007 3. Council directive 93/42/EEC concerning medical devices, 2007  4. Handbook of medical device regulatory affairs in Asia, Jack Wong and Raymond Tong, Pan Stanford Publishing, 2013 5. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating New Medical Technologies, Stefanos A Zenios; Josh Makower; Paul G Yock , Cambridge University Press, 2010
recommended_readings: N/A

title: Biomedical Modelling
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4190.
description: This course covers basic physiologic systems: neuromuscular system, auditory system, pulmonary-cardiovascular system and etc. It also covers bioelectric phenomena including action potentials, cellular membrane models, volume conductor models, ECG, EMG, EEG, etc. It also discusses biomedical modelling including lumped element model, bio-impedance and otoacoustic emissions. It concludes with topics in bio-modelling of recent interest.

title: Body Sensor Networks
description: The course aims at providing an introduction to wearable medical devices and bio-sensing technologies. Major topics include design of on-body and in-body biosensors, communication topologies, protocols, standards and media of body sensor networks (BSN). It introduces the usages and roles of BSN in real-life applications. Selected issues in state-of-the-art development of BSN, e.g. information security, signal interference, energy scavenging, multi-sensor fusion and context-aware sensing.

title: Biomedical Imaging Applications
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4200. Prerequisite: BMEG3320 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course provides knowledge and technical background on the current available bio-imaging technologies developed for assessment of quality of musculoskeletal tissues. The emphasis lies on their application for bone and cartilage (e.g. QCT, pQCT, microCT for animals and human, nano-CT, MRI, ultrasound, and other advanced imaging modalities). Contrast-enhancement media for musculoskeletal and vascular applications, use of above bioimaging modalities for evaluation of scaffold biomaterials developed for enhancement of repair of musculoskeletal tissues. It also covers applications of biomedical imaging in diagnosis, prevention and treatment of aging related disorders of musculoskeletal, cardiovascular and other relevant living systems.

title: Advanced Imaging and Spectroscopy Techniques in Biomedicine
requirements: Prerequisite: BMEG3320.;Not for students who have taken ESTR4201.
description: This course introduces and discusses medical imaging and treatment techniques which make use of sound and electromagnetic waves (e.g., ultrasound, laser, terahertz, etc.) for biomedical imaging and spectroscopy. The lectures will be divided into the following three main topics: (1) Ultrasound imaging techniques and applications: wave propagation theory (wave equation, transmission and reflection coefficients, attenuation, instrumentation and therapeutics), sonography design aspects, and medically relevant examples; (2) Optical imaging and spectroscopy basics and techniques; and (3) Laser techniques for medical treatments: photodynamic therapy, laser surgery.

title: BioMEMS
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4203.
description: BioMEMS is the application of MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) technology in the fields of biomedical and health sciences. Due to their small size (1 μm ~ 1 mm), BioMEMS have the advantages of low weight, low cost, quick response, high throughput, high efficiency, requiring much less sample/reagent, and easy system integration. BioMEMS has found broad applications in disease diagnosis, prevention, and treatment. Various bioMEMS products have been developed, such as microfluidic devices, neural interface devices, μTAS (micro Total Analysis Systems), Lab-on-a-Chip, DNA Chips, micro drug delivery system, microsurgical tools, biosensors. This course covers the introduction of BioMEMS, techniques used in constructing the devices, patterning biomolecules, biomedical problems that can be addressed by the BioMEMS technology, as well as the associated engineering challenges.

title: Bionanotechnology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4202.
description: This course consists of two parts. The first half covers basic concepts in nanotechnology (e.g., length scales (less than 100 nm) effect on properties of materials and devices), and introduces techniques and tools for fabricating nanostructured and bioengineered materials: quantum dots, DNA, self-assembly and templating, surface patterning, and functionalization. The second half introduces three key applications of nanotechnology in biomedical research (i.e., diagnostics, in vivo imaging, and targeted drug delivery), and briefly discusses the process of translating laboratory discoveries to therapies applicable in clinical trials.

title: Biomolecular Engineering
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4204. Pre-requisite: SBMS1440 or with the consent of the course instructor.
description: This course consists of two parts. The first half covers basic concepts in biomolecular engineering, including structure and properties of biomolecules (e.g., nucleic acid, protein, lipid, and sugar), the central dogma of molecular biology, and regulation of gene expression. Building on the theoretical framework from the first half, the second half introduces experimental tools involved in biomolecular engineering research, including synthesis and characterization of DNA and protein, gene recombination, and basic genomics. Set at the advanced undergraduate level, the course focuses on developing students’ ability to analyze research data and critique the scientific literature.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to able to: 1. understand the tools and concepts of biomolecular engineering; 2. interpret data from and formulate hypothesis based on research in biomolecular engineering and offer objective critiques to the scientific literature; 3. appreciate the impact of biomolecular engineering from intellectual, clinical and commercial perspectives
syllabus: This course consists of two parts. The first half covers basic concepts in biomolecular engineering, including structure and properties of biomolecules (e.g., nucleic acid, protein, lipid, and sugar), the central dogma of molecular biology, and regulation of gene expression. Building on the theoretical framework from the first half, the second half introduces experimental tools involved in biomolecular engineering research, including synthesis and characterization of DNA and protein, gene recombination, and basic genomics. Set at the advanced undergraduate level, the course focuses on developing students’ ability to analyze research data and critique the scientific literature.
recommended_readings: J. M. Berg, J. L. Tymoczko, and L. Stryer. Biochemistry. W. H. Freeman, 7th edition, 2012.  R. F. Weaver. Molecular biology. McGraw-Hill, 5th edition, 2011. Other book chapters, review articles, and reference readings will be distributed in class.

title: Cardiovascular Engineering
description: The course topics include nanomedicine for managing cardiovascular diseases (targeted delivery, imaging agents, and therapeutic agents), electrocardiography, pacemaker, defibrillator, physiology and disease (endothelial cell, macrophage, and atherosclerosis), cardiovascular fluid mechanics (blood rheology, endothelial shear stress, stenosis), introduction and application of stem cells (differentiation, regeneration, cell replacement, modeling heart diseases), and clinical applications.
outcome: By the end of this course, students are expected to: 1. Understand the basic concepts and terminology in biology and engineering; 2. Cite examples to learn fundamental thought processes; 3. Gain practice in using scientific literature; 4. Learn about practical approaches and limitations.
syllabus: The course topics include: nanomedicine for managing cardiovascular diseases (targeted delivery, Imaging agents, and therapeutic agents), electrocardiography, pacemaker, defibrillator, physiology and disease (endothelial cell, macrophage, and atherosclerosis), cardiovascular fluid mechanics (blood rheology, endothelial shear stress, stenosis), introduction and application of stem cells (differentiation, regeneration, cell replacement, modeling heart diseases), clinical applications.  More details will be provided when available.
required_readings: 1. Handbook of Cardiac Anatomy, Physiology, and Devices, Paul A. Iaizzo, Springer, 3rd edition, 2015.2. Biofluid Mechanics: The Human Circulation, Krishnan B. Chandran, Stanley E. Rittgers, Ajit P. Yoganathan, CRC Press, 2nd edition, 2012.
recommended_readings: N/A

title: Musculoskeletal Tissue Engineering
requirements: Prerequisite: BMEG3430 or with the consent of the instructor.;Not for students who have taken ESTR4214.
description: This course introduces the application of the principles of biology and engineering to the development of viable substitutes which restore, maintain, or improve the function of musculoskeletal tissues. Topics include musculoskeletal tissues: tissue engineering of tendon/ligament, cartilage and bone. It focuses on the understanding the interactions between extracellular matrices and cells, mechanobiological responses of cells/tissues. It also discusses musculoskeletal biomaterials including the development of bioactive, biomimetic advanced biological materials for replacement of aged and diseased musculoskeletal tissues.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Understand the fundamentals and characteristics of tissue and musculoskeletal engineering. 2. Understand the development and modeling of different biomaterials. 3. Understand the musculoskeletal tissues related to tendon/ligament, cartilage, bone, and the interaction between extracellular matrix and cells. 4. Understand and measure mechanobiological responses of cells/tissues. 5. Appreciate the use of bioactive, biomimetic advanced biological materials for replacement of aged and diseased musculoskeletal tissues.
syllabus: This course introduces the application of the principles of biology and engineering to the development of viable substitutes which restore, maintain, or improve the function of musculoskeletal tissues. Topics include musculoskeletal tissues: tissue engineering of tendon/ligament, cartilage and bone. It focuses on the understanding the interactions between extracellular matrices and cells, mechanobiological responses of cells/tissues. It also discusses musculoskeletal biomaterials including the development of bioactive, biomimetic advanced biological materials for replacement of aged and diseased musculoskeletal tissues.  More details will be provided when available.
required_readings: BME       Novartis Foundation. Tissue Engineering of Cartilage and Bone. Wiley. ISBN: 978-0470844816

title: Final Year Project I
description: The course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to carry out, under the supervision of an academic staff, an independent project with research elements in engineering.
outcome: By the end of the course, students are expected to 1) Be able to identify and have a basic understanding of the literature related to the project topic. 2) Be able to define and complete a project that utilizes results in the literature. 3) Be able to perform a critical review of the project. 4) Develop technical writing skills.
syllabus: The course includes, but are not limited to, the following elements: literature review, modelling, system design and implementation, project evaluation.
required_readings: Literature review materials will be recommended by the project supervisor.
recommended_readings: N/A     N/A

title: Advanced Medical Robotics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering
description: The course covers medical robotics fundamentals, including introduction to robotics enabled endoscopic and laparoscopic surgeries, concepts of robotics based minimal invasive surgeries and robotic technologies in Da Vinci surgical system, micro-scale robotic medical devices, robotic technologies in natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) systems, visions and image processing in medical and surgical robotic systems, introduction to rehabilitation, and prosthetic robotic technology and systems.

title: Biomedical Image Processing
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering
description: The course introduces advanced theories, algorithms and techniques on biomedical image processing and analysis. The course content covers compressive sensing for MRI and Terahertz imaging, biomedical image reconstruction, sample characterization methods in reflection and transmission geometry, image interpolation, image deconvolution, image segmentation, and image registration. It also includes some biomedical image applications, such as Terahertz spectroscopy and diffusion tensor MRI. Students who take this course need background on signal processing and MATLAB programming.

title: Rehabilitation Engineering
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or;For students in BEng Biomedical Engineering
description: The course introduces the disabling process, aging and disabilities, congenital disabilities, the enabling process and therapeutic equipment in rehabilitation medicine. It covers assistive technologies for persons with physical disabilities, sensory disorders, communication disorders, mental disabilities, and technologies for learning, work and leisure, accessible technology and universal design. Appropriate technology for the developing regions.

title: Biomedical Engineering Seminar I
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering
description: A series of seminars related to the topics of biomedical engineering are delivered by local and oversea biomedical engineering scholars and researchers. CUHK BME postgraduate students are required to attend at least six BME seminars during one semester and write two reports on their learning from two seminars, respectively.
outcome: PG Students are expected to:  1. Understand diverse research topics on biomedical engineering  2. Understand societal and scientific impact of biomedical engineering research 3. Acquire knowledge in biomedical engineering’s on-going research
syllabus: biomaterials and regenerative medicine, medical instrumentation and biosensors, biomolecular engineering and nanomedicine, biomedical imaging and informatics
recommended_readings: 1. Writing Essays in English Language and Linguistics, by Murray, N. 2012, Cambridge University Press. 2. Academic Writing for Graduate Students: Essential Tasks and Skills, by John M. Swales, Christine A. Beer Feak, Christine Feak, 2nd Edition, 2004 by University of Michigan Press 3. The Elements of Style, by William Strunk Jr., E.B. White, 3rd 1999 by Longman

title: Tissue Engineering
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course provides an overview on the fundamental elements of tissue engineering including stem cell, extracellular matrix, biomaterials, soluble factor, drug delivery, mechanotransduction and bioreactor and recent advances in these fields. This course helps the students to understand how knowledge and techniques from biochemistry, biology, material science and various engineering disciplines can be applied to promote the advancement in tissue engineering of various physiological systems. Basic level of knowledge in biomaterials, biology and biochemistry is recommended.

title: Bio-MEMS and Biophotonics
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course covers an introduction to MEMS and photonics technologies, with focus on biomedical applications. Topics include: introduction to cell and tissues, DNA and protein, recent developments in BioMEMS, micro-fluidic systems, integrated DNA analysis chips, micro-fabricated bio-detection and cell-sorting systems, interaction between light and biological materials, photoabsorption, emission and spectroscopy, bio-imaging principles and techniques, light-activated therapy, laser tweezers, and emerging MEMS and biophotonic technologies.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should demonstrate the following outcomes: - capacity to design and analyze microfluidic sensors and actuators, micro total analysis systems and lab-on-a-chip; - have a brief picture of how photonic techniques may be used for analyzing biological materials; - clear understanding of the operation of various optical sources and detection devices; - understanding of optical imaging principle and systems; and - appreciation of emerging MEMS and biophotonic techniques.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Text: Paras N. Prasad,"Introduction to Biophotonics" Wiley-Interscience, 2003 "Introduction of BioMEMS" by Albert Folch, CRC Press, 2013 "Bio-MEMS: Technologies and Applications" by Wanjun Wang and Steven A. Soper, CRC Press, 2006 "Introduction to Microfabrication" by Sami Franssila, John Wiley & Sons, 2010 "Fundamentals and Applications of Microfluidics", by Nam-Trung Nguyen and Steve Wereley, Artech Print on Demand, 2006  Internet resources: Various website related to course contents

title: Research Methods in Biomedical Engineering
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in BEng Biomedical Engineering
description: This course presents research methods in biomedical engineering, and primarily aims at preparing postgraduate students for basic research or employment in the clinic and biomedical industries. Students will learn relevant concepts and tools for analyzing data arising from quantitative and qualitative research in molecular, physiological, and clinical systems. This course focuses on developing students’ ability to analyze research data and critique the scientific literature.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Understand basic concepts in hypothesis-driven research and design research;  2. Apply statistical tools, packages, or models to design experiments and interpret research and/or clinical data;  3. Communicate statistical data through reports and oral presentations effectively; and 4. Evaluate scientific literature in biomedical engineering critically.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: W     W. W. Daniel and C. L. Cross. Biostatistics: A foundation for analysis in the health sciences. Wiley, 10th edition, 2013.  D. G. Altman. Practical statistics for medical research. Chapman and Hall/ CRC, 1st edition, 1990.  Other book chapters, review articles, and reference readings will be distributed in class.

title: Guided Study in Biomedical Engineering
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering
description: This course allows a student or a group of students to study an advanced topic in biomedical engineering under the guidance of a faculty member, especially when there is no such course being offered on the topic in that period of time. This course could underpin but not be directly taken as thesis research and should not be taught by the student’s supervisor. Examples of guided studies include the areas of (A) biomaterials & regenerative medicine, (B) biomolecular engineering & nanomedicine, (C) biomedical imaging & informatics, (D) biomedical instrumentation & sensors, and (E) others. A student in this course is normally required to (a) complete a series of reading assignments, (b) audit in part or in full a related course, an intensive workshop or a thematic symposium, and/or (c) conduct a self study on a related topic. For assessment purpose, the student is normally required to pass a written examination on (a) and (b), and to deliver an oral presentation on (c). The total student learning effort is expected to be around 120-140 hrs. The level of learning attained should be on par with a research postgraduate course. A Graduate Panel member will be appointed by the Division Head to serve as an associate examiner at the oral examination and to moderate the written examination paper. Upon completion of the course, the responsible faculty member should submit to the Examination Panel a written report on the list of reading materials assigned, a record of the course/ workshop/ symposium the student(s) completed, the power-points presented, the written examination paper and the answers given by the student(s).

title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course introduces the definition, scope, basic principles and problems in biomedical engineering. Students will learn applications of technology to medicine and biology, contemporary issues and roles of engineering applied to complex biological systems and brief description of professional ethics.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. To understand definition, scope, basic principles and problems in biomedical engineering;  2. Able to apply technology to medicine and biology;  3. To understand contemporary issues and roles of engineering applied to biological systems; and 4. To understand the importance of professional ethics.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. Introduction to Biomedical Engineering, 3rd edition, by John Enderle and Joseph Bronzino, Publisher: Elsevier Academic, 2011.

title: Basic Biomedical Science
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course introduces students to the basic anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry of human body. The course provides a system-based review of the structure and function, normal as well as abnormal, of different organ systems. Emphases will be placed on those structures/functions that are important in biomedical engineering, especially the nervous system and the musculoskeletal system. Case studies will also be included to introduce the importance of medical sciences related to biomedical engineering.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to describe the functions of the major organ systems of the body, including the endocrine, nervous, cardiovascular, kidney and respiratory systems; 2. Able to explain the basic anatomy of the human body especially with respect to the skull, vertebral columns and limbs; 3. Able to describe the basic chemical constituents of the body and their functions, and the concepts of genomics, bioinformatics & protein engineering; 4. Able to explain the concepts of tissue engineering, biomechanics and rehabilitation engineering;  5. Able to explain the origins of neuronal and other bioelectric signals and their recording methods; and 6. Able to elucidate case studies that illustrate the importance of medical sciences in relation to biomedical engineering.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. Introduction to Biomedical Engineering by John D Enderle &D Bronzino   Publisher: Elsevier 2012. ISBN: 978-0-12-374979-6 2. Orthopaedic Basic Sciences by Buckwalter JA, Einhorn T, Simon SR eds.:   Publisher: American Academy of Orhopaedic Surgeons, 2000  (Chinese Version: Chan KM, Leung KS, Qin L, Hu YY, Wang SH, Zhong SZ, Dai KR (eds.), Peoples’ Medical Publishing House, Beijing, PR China. ISBN 7-117-04569-8 (total pages: 735), December 2001 (陳啟明, 梁國穗, 秦嶺主編. 骨科基礎科學(中文版第一版) (735頁). 人民衛生出版社 2001)

title: Medical Devices and Sensor Networks
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course introduces the origins of physiological signals, the mechanisms of bioelectrical, biochemical, biophysical, and biophotonic sensors. It covers the principles of wearable medical devices for homecare and mobile health care system. Students will learn features of body sensor networks (BSN), security issues for BSN, multi-sensor data fusion for BSN, wearable and implantable sensor integration, wearable devices and sensors for monitoring, diagnosis, therapy, spots, etc. and applications of medical devices, biosensors, and BSN.

title: Medical Robotics
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course covers the introduction to robotics and its applications in biomedical engineering including diagnosis, surgery, and medical simulation. Students will learn the classification of robot systems, forward and inverse kinematics associated to manipulator motion, robot design, control, sensing, and programming.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Understand fundamentals of medical robotics; 2. Know how to derive the forward kinematics of robot manipulator; 3. Be familiar with the inverse kinematics of robot manipulator; 4. Understand human-robots interface and its importance in medical robots; 5. Understand tele-robotics and its medical applications; 6. Understand fundamentals of robot control; 7. Be knowledgeable with novel robotic applications in medical care; and 8. Be knowledgeable with surgical robotics.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: [1]. John Craig, ‘Introduction to Robotics: Mechanics and Control’, 4th edition, Pearson, ISBN 978-0133489798 [2]. Kevin M. Lynch and Frank C. Park, ‘Modern Robotics: Mechanics, Planning and Control’, Cambridge, ISBN 978-1107156302 [3]. Peter Corke, ‘Robotics, Vision and Control: Fundamental Algorithms in MATLAB’, Springer, ISBN: 978-3642201431 [4]. Jacob Rosen, Blake Hannaford, Richard M. Satava, ‘Surgical Robotics: Systems Applications and Visions’, Springer, ISBN 978-1441911254

title: Bioelectronics and Nanotechnology
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course covers the essential elements of bioelectronics and nanotechnology specific to biomedical engineering. The first part of this course (Bioelectronics) includes overview of bioelectronics, functional materials for bioelectronics, biomolecule-based transistors, electrochemical biosensors, device fabrication and characterisation, lab-on-a-chip, wearable devices, and implantable bioelectronics and bionics.The second part of this course (Nanotechnology) includes introduction to nanotechnology, nanolithography, solution-based synthesis of nano-materials, characterisation techniques, scanning probe-based biomanipulation, soft-lithography for DNA, proteins and cells, self-assembly of peptides and proteins, nanoscale drug delivery systems, and bio-nano-informatics fusion.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:- Understand the essential elements of bioelectronics and nanotechnology in the context that it is the fusion between biotechnology and nanotechnology; - Appreciate the impact of bioelectronics and nanotechnology in the field of biomedical engineering; and- Understand the key processing technologies involved in the fabrication of practical devices based on bioelectronics concepts and nanotechnology.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

title: Bioinformatics
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course covers DNA, RNA and protein bioinformatics. It introduces basic understanding into bioinformatics, biostatistics, programming techniques, sequence analysis, database search, pattern recognition, and clustering structural prediction.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to recognize the importance of bioinformatics; 2. Able to perform basic protein and DNA sequence analyses, including alignment of sequence; 3. Able to do basic searches in common databases to aid in applied bioinformatics analyses; 4. Able to perform basic statistical analysis; and 5. Able to describe the fundamental aspects of phylogenetic trees, scoring matrices, pattern recognition, clustering and structural prediction.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Bioinformatics for Beginners: Genes, Genomes, Molecular Evolution, Databases and Analytical Tool (Hardcover; May 26, 2014) by Supratim Choudhuri (Author); ISBN-13: 978-0124104716 ISBN-10: 0124105106 (available as online book at CUHK Library: search for “0124105106”)

title: Virtual Medicine and Computer Aided Surgery
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course introduces the image guided surgery, including CT base, fluoro-image, and others, non-image guided surgery. It covers the introduction to clinical applications, virtual reality and surgical simulation, augmented reality, image-guided minimally invasive surgery, use of telerobotics in surgery, and surgical navigation.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. To understand the principles and clinical applications of image guided and non-image guide computer aided surgeries; 2. To understand the principles and clinical application of robot assisted surgery; 3. To understand the principles and application of e-medicine with clinical management system; 4. To understand the principles of Virtual Reality and surgical simulation and Augmented reality and image-guided minimally invasive surgery; 5. To introduce the use of telerobotics in surgery; and 6. With a variety of proposed projects, students will have a first hand information and practical experience on the further understanding of the above knowledge conveyed in the lectures.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

title: Medical Imaging
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: The course introduces various diagnostic medical imaging modalities, such as projection radiography, conventional X-ray, computerized tomography (CT), nuclear medicine (PET and SPECT), ultrasound, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Each of these modalities will be introduced from basic physical principles to the process of image formation. This course also reviews the basic signal processing techniques and introduces the image processing and analysis.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. To use the basic digital image processing background to understand image acquisition, sampling and reconstruction, image segmentation, image filtering; 2. To use fundamental concept for medical visualization; 3. To understand the basic physical principles for clinical applications of several relevant clinical medical imaging devices, including X-ray fluoroscopy, radiography, ultrasound, computed tomography (CT) and imaging guided therapy; 4. To be able to follow the terahertz principle to apply terahertz imaging and spectroscopy in biomedicine; 5. To understand the basics of cellular and molecular imaging and major imaging modalities, including Laser Scanning Confocal Microscopy, Light and Fluorescence Microscopy and In vivo molecular imaging for small animal; 6. To understand the basis of Medical Imaging Based Bone Densitometry, including DXA, pQCT, and microCT) and their application in diagnosis of osteoporosis; and  7. To understand the basic principles of medical imaging-based Finite Element Analysis (FEA).
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Fundamentals of Medical Imaging by Paul Suetens Online version: http://ebooks.cambridge.org/ebook.jsf?bid=CBO9780511596803

title: Biomedical Engineering Laboratories
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course aims to provide students from different science & engineering backgrounds opportunities to learn how to fabricate simple medical materials and devices, how to collect data on human subjects and other biological samples, and how to analyze the results to address various health-related issues. The course starts with a series of lectures on the principles underpinning each of the planned laboratory modules. Students will then form teams to conduct a number of hand-on laboratory modules in different areas of biomedical engineering to achieve the course aims and learning outcomes. Examples of laboratory modules include fabrication of basic biomedical device for biosignal acquisition, advanced electrophysiological techniques, fabrication of biomaterials for drug deliveries, PCR and gel electrophoresis, confocal fluorescence microscopy, functional MRI data processing, biomedical imaging for musculoskeletal applications, measurement of interfacial pressure at body support surfaces, electromyography & exoskeleton hand robot, etc.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to demonstrate the basic attitudes and skills needed to conduct BME measurements on human subjects and on other biological specimens; 2. Able to articulate the fundamental principles underpinning those BME measurements; and 3. Able to perform quantitative analysis of the data collected to address related biomedical issues.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
required_readings: Lecture and laboratory notes for each laboratory session.
recommended_readings: 1. Dally JW, Riley WF, McConnel KG. Instrumentation for Engineering Measurements. 2nd Edition. Wiley. 1993. 2. Enderle JD, Blanchard SM, Bronzino JD. Introduction to Biomedical Engineering. Second Edition. Elsevier. 2005. 3. Saltzman WM. Biomedical Engineering – Bridging Medicine and Technology. Cambridge. 2009. 4. Semmlow J. Signals and Systems for Bioengineers. 2nd Edition. Academic Press. 2011. 5. Drzewiecki G. Laboratory Manual for Biomedical Engineering: Devices and Systems. Cognella Academic Publishing. 2012 6. Campbell ID. Biophysical Techniques. Oxford. 2012.

title: Medical Device Regulatory Affairs and Intellectual Property
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering;Not for students who have taken BMEG4010
description: This course provides an overview on medical device regulation and intellectual property. Regulatory affairs is how to get a medical product registered in different countries’ health authorities. A registered product would demand a lot of technical documentation to prove its efficacy, safety, and quality. To successfully and smoothly register a product, knowledge and skills are required to deal with various key stakeholders in governments, testing centers, hospitals, and medical doctors. Intellectual Property, such as patent, is to protect the invention and to support licensing their rights to manufacturers in the medical device industry.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to describe how to meet standards and regulatory requirements of medical devices in US, Europe and Asia; 2. Able to demonstrate an understanding of the practical knowledge about intellectual property, such as patent; and  3. Able to describe how to apply and file a patent application, and issues related to patent defence.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
required_readings: 1. Medical devices – Quality management systems – Requirements for regulatory purposes ISO13485:2003, 2003 2. Medical devices — Application of risk management to medical devices ISO14971:2007, 2007 3. Council directive 93/42/EEC concerning medical devices, 2007  4. Handbook of medical device regulatory affairs in Asia, Jack Wong and Raymond Tong, Pan Stanford Publishing, 2013 5. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating New Medical Technologies, Stefanos A Zenios; Josh Makower; Paul G Yock , Cambridge University Press, 2010 6. Patent it yourself, 11th edition, David Pressmann, Berkeley, CA : Nolo. 2005

title: E-Health Technologies
requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or ;For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science
description: This course introduces the concepts of tele-medicine, electronic-medicine (E-health), and mobile-health (M-health). It covers basic techniques in tele-medicine and M-health, namely communication systems and networks, medical devices, E-medical records, information security and confidentiality, medical data coding and compression, functions of picture archiving and communication systems (PACS) and health information systems (HIS). Applications of E-health technologies, which include tele-surgery, tele-geriatrics, tele-monitoring and M-health etc, will be covered.

requirements: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: The objective of this course is for students to get hands-on practical experience. Each student is required to design, simulate or test a medical device/ algorithm / bioinformatics database.

title: Thesis Research
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering
description: In this course, a student is required to meet regularly with his/her supervisor individually and/or in small group, to receive guidance and supervision to conduct his/her thesis research and to write up his/her thesis.
outcome: Under the regular supervision of the thesis advisor, the student learns how to formulate a research question in an area of his/her interest, articulate the long-term goals and shorter-term objectives of his/her research, critically review the background literatures, plan and conduct the research activities, become competent in the underpinning knowledge and skills, analyze, present and discuss the results thoroughly, and draw appropriate conclusions based on the findings. The student is expected to mature as a more independent researcher as he/she progresses in his/her research study.
syllabus: In this course, a student is required to meet regularly with his/her supervisor individually and/or in small group, to receive guidance and supervision to conduct his/her thesis research and to write up his/her thesis.
recommended_readings: Individually assigned by the thesis advisor.
